title: Dejen Aviation Engineering Industry
text:
The Dejen Aviation Engineering Industry (DAVI) is a center for overhauling and upgrading <a href="military%20aircraft">military aircraft</a>. Its primary objective is to provide depot level maintenance and carry out upgrading/modification to the fleet of the <a href="Ethiopian%20Air%20Force">Ethiopian Air Force</a>. It is one of the Defense organizations of the <a href="Defense%20Industry%20Sector%20%28Ethiopia%29">Ethiopian Defense Industry</a> under the <a href="Ministry%20of%20Defense%20%28Ethiopia%29">Ministry of Defense</a>.
History.
The aircraft overhauling center was started in mid-1980s as a project under the name Aircraft Heavy Maintenance Center to overhaul <a href="Mikoyan-Gurevich%20MiG-21">MiG-21</a> and <a href="Mikoyan-Gurevich%20MiG-23">MiG-23</a> aircraft of the Ethiopian Air Force. The center was intended to have a capacity for overhauling 50 aircraft annually. It never reached full capability by the time the <a href="Ethiopian%20Civil%20War">civil war</a> ended in 1991.
In 1995, the transitional government started reevaluating the project. A team was formed from different organizations and the scope of the center was enlarged to include overhaul of helicopters and transports in addition to fighters as well as carry out upgrade/modification work. The project was implemented in phases and the center was formally inaugurated in 2004.
